Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (in endemic areas)

justification: Kawasaki disease is a rare but serious illness that primarily affects children under 5 years of age. It is characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels. The presence of fever, diffuse erythematous rash, hand erythema (redness), conjunctivitis, and periungal desquamation (peeling skin around the nails) are highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease. }, {diagnosis: Scarlet fever

justification: Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection caused by group A Streptococcus. It typically presents with fever, sore throat, a characteristic red rash that feels like sandpaper, and a strawberry tongue. While not as common as in other symptoms, periungal desquamation, hand erythema, and conjunctivitis can occur in scarlet fever.}, {diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (SJS/TEN)

justification: SJS/TEN are rare, life-threatening skin reactions that usually occur as a severe adverse reaction to medications. While SJS/TEN typically manifest with painful, widespread skin detachment, early signs can include fever, conjunctivitis, and a diffuse erythematous rash. Periungal desquamation and hand erythema may also be present.}, {diagnosis: Viral exanthem

justification: Viral exanthems are rashes that often accompany viral infections, especially in children. The specific symptoms can vary widely depending on the virus, but fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and periungal desquamation are possible features. Hand erythema could be part of the rash manifestation.}, {diagnosis: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: DRESS syndrome is a severe drug reaction characterized by fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, and multi-organ involvement. While less specific than some other symptoms, hand erythema, periungal desquamation, and conjunctivitis can occur as part of the cutaneous manifestations of DRESS.}, {diagnosis: Hand, foot, and mouth disease

justification: Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a common viral infection that typically affects infants and young children. Its characterized by painful sores in the mouth, on the palms of the hands, and on the soles of the feet. While not as common, a rash can also appear on other parts of the body, and conjunctivitis has been reported. Periungal desquamation can occur as a later manifestation of the illness. }, {diagnosis: Measles

justification: Measles is a highly contagious viral infection characterized by fever, cough, runny nose, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic red, blotchy rash. While less common, periungal desquamation can occur during the recovery phase of measles. Hand erythema may be part of the rash.}, {diagnosis: Toxic shock syndrome (TSS)

justification: TSS is a rare but life-threatening condition caused by toxins produced by certain bacteria. Its characterized by fever, hypotension, a diffuse erythematous rash, and multi-organ involvement. While less common than other symptoms, periungal desquamation and conjunctivitis can occur in TSS. Hand erythema may be part of the diffuse rash.}, {diagnosis: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

justification: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and heart. Skin involvement is common and can manifest as a butterfly rash on the face, photosensitivity, and other rashes. Periungal desquamation, hand erythema, and conjunctivitis can occur in SLE.}, {diagnosis: Leptospirosis

justification: Leptospirosis is a bacterial infection spread through contact with contaminated water or soil. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, headache, muscle aches, conjunctivitis, and a rash. Periungal desquamation and hand erythema can occur as part of the rash.}
